intro: Phyllanthus callidiscus, commonly known as the African sandalwood, is a shrub native to tropical Africa. It belongs to the family Euphorbiaceae and is characterized by its small, greenish-yellow flowers and capsule fruits. The plant typically grows in sandy or rocky soils and is often found in coastal areas. It has hairy leaves and produces a milky sap that is sometimes used in traditional medicine. Its ecological importance includes providing habitat and food for various insects and small animals.
